org.strykeforce.thirdcoast.swerve

Class SwerveDrive

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.strykeforce.thirdcoast.swerve.SwerveDrive

  • public class SwerveDrive
extends Object
    Control a Third Coast swerve drive. Wheels are numbered 0-3 from front to back, with even numbers on the left side when facing forward.

    Derivation of inverse kinematic equations are from Ether's Swerve Kinematics and Programming.

    See Also:
    Wheel

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static SwerveDrive getInstance()
        Get the drive subsystem singleton. This is lazy initialized to avoid UnsatisfiedLinkError against the CTRE JNI libs during unit testing.
        Returns:
        the drive singleton

      • set

        public void set(double azimuth,
                double drive)
        Set all four wheels to specified values.
        Parameters:
        azimuth - -0.5 to 0.5 rotations, measured clockwise with zero being the robot straight-ahead position
        drive - 0 to 1 in the direction of the wheel azimuth

      • drive

        public void drive(double forward,
                  double strafe,
                  double azimuth)
        Drive the robot in given field-relative direction and with given rotation.
        Parameters:
        forward - Y-axis movement, from -1.0 (reverse) to 1.0 (forward)
        strafe - X-axis movement, from -1.0 (left) to 1.0 (right)
        azimuth - robot rotation, from -1.0 (CCW) to 1.0 (CW)

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops all wheels' azimuth and drive movement. Calling this in the robots teleopInit and autonomousInit will reset wheel azimuth relative encoders to the current position and thereby prevent wheel rotation if the wheels were moved manually while the robot was disabled.

      • saveAzimuthPositions

        public void saveAzimuthPositions()
        Save the wheels' azimuth current position as read by absolute encoder. These values are saved persistently on the roboRIO and are normally used to calculate the relative encoder offset during wheel initialization.

        The wheel alignment data is saved in the WPI preferences data store and may be viewed using a network tables viewer.

        See Also:
        zeroAzimuthEncoders()

      • zeroAzimuthEncoders

        public void zeroAzimuthEncoders()
        Set wheels' azimuth relative offset from zero based on the current absolute position. This uses the physical zero position as read by the absolute encoder and saved during the wheel alignment process.
        See Also:
        saveAzimuthPositions()

      • getGyro

        public com.kauailabs.navx.frc.AHRS getGyro()
        Get the gyro instance being used by the drive.
        Returns:
        the gyro instance
